text: In 2014, 13% of Alabama’s children participate in an afterschool program, compared to 15% in 2009 and 10% in 2004.
title: Afterschool program participation in Alabama

text: For the purposes of this study, timing was limited to 15 hours per week in afterschool care, reflecting the hours of 3 to 6 p.m.
title: Average time per week children spend in an afterschool program

text: In 2014, 41% of Alabama’s children would participate in an afterschool program if one were available, compared to 36% in 2009 and 36% in 2004.
title: Children who would participate if an afterschool program were available

text: In 2014, 19% of Alabama’s children are alone and unsupervised between the hours of 3 and 6 p.m., for an average of 8.11 hours per week.
title: Children unsupervised after school

text: 65% Alabama parents agree that afterschool programs can help children gain workforce skills such as teamwork, leadership and critical thinking.
title: Parents agree that afterschool programs help children gain workforce skills

text: 83% Alabama parents agree that afterschool programs can help reduce the likelihood that youth will engage in risky behaviors, such as commit a crime, abuse drugs or engage in sexual activity.
title: Parents agree that afterschool programs reduce the likelihood that youth will engage in risky behaviors

text: In 2014, 94% of Alabama’s parents are satisfied with their child’s afterschool program, compared to 89% in 2009 and 91% in 2004.
title: Parents satisfied with their child’s afterschool program

text: In 2014, 2% of Alabama’s children in grades K-5 were unsupervised after school, compared to 12% in grades 6-8 and 32% in grades 9-12.
title: Children unsupervised after school, by grade

text: In 2014, 18% of Alabama’s children in grades K-5 participate in an afterschool program, compared to 12% in grades 6-8 and 8% in grades 9-12.

text: of Alabama parents support public funding for afterschool programs, while just 8% report receiving government assistance with the cost of afterschool.
title: of Alabama parents agree that afterschool programs help give working parents peace of mind about their children when they are at work.

text: Most families piece together a variety of afterschool solutions, with 69% of Alabama’s K-12 children spending some portion of the hours after school in the care of a parent or guardian.  Other afterschool arrangements include traditional child care centers (7%); sibling care (13%); and non-parental adult care, such as a grandparent or neighbor (29%).

After lack of need, the predominant obstacles parents face enrolling their child in an afterschool program include:

  • Preference for alternative activities
  • Afterschool programs would not benefit their child
title: What barriers to afterschool program enrollment are Alabama families facing?

text: In Alabama, 203 households and 793 children were screened for this study. According to the Department of Education, National Center for Education Statistics data for 2011-2012, the total school enrollment in Alabama is 783,343, which is the foundation for all statewide projections in STATE After 3PM.
